How To.title: Developing a Business Case
How To.summary: To make a compelling argument about your idea for a project or organisation, it helps to be able to present your rationale from a few angles. You can argue why it is  viable using Five Cases Model prepared by HM Treasury.

How To.title: Starting New Business Advice
How To.summary: Have an idea but not sure how to go about going ahead with it? You can get a support from the Go For It Programme, which provides step-by-step advice and mentoring to guide founders towards the launch and success of their businesses.

How To.title: Funding sports projects
How To.summary: The best organisation to turn to for financial support for a project concerned with physical activities is Sport NI. They always have a few funding programmes on the go, which you can apply for!

How To.title: Starting a Community Group
How To.summary: If you are working with other towards a shared goal but you do not have a formal group, why not start one? It can give you more leverage in advancing your agenda as well as provide practical benefits such as being able to receive funding.

How To.title: Planning Your Project
How To.summary: This provides a template for project planning and evaluation provided by the Department of Economy.

How To.title: Starting a Social Enterprose
How To.summary: Programmes and resources for those wanting to start a social enterprise and cooperatives in Northern Ireland.

How To.title: Funding
How To.summary: An online resource sharing all information about grants.

How To.title: Settling into a Community
How To.summary: This resource links you to a Community Welcome Pack  to help you settle into your local community.

How To.title: Restorative Justice
How To.summary: Northern Ireland Alternatives (NIA) is a government accredited restorative justice programme that aims to promote and develop non-violent community responses to the issues of low-level crime and anti-social behaviour in areas across Northern Ireland. N,E & S Belfast, Greater Shankill and N.Down.

How To.title: Community Garden
How To.summary: A range of resources from videos to start- up guides for creating your own community garden in North Belfast.

How To.title: Enterprise Advice
How To.summary: A service run by the North City Business Centre offers a range of business support services to assist entrepreneurs in starting a business.

How To.title: Personal and Family Development
How To.summary: Training and development opportunities provided by Ashton Community Trust including for “essential skills” and around employability.

How To.title: Forward South Partnership
How To.summary: A charity  that works with community, schools, business, public and private sector partners to help regenerate and sustain a healthy and prosperous South Belfast.

How To.title: Employability South
How To.summary: A market development association designed to offer support to individuals from the local communities of South Belfast.

How To.title: Market Development Association
How To.summary: An association that seeks to advocate on behalf of the Market community on socio-economic issues which impact on the residents by adopting a community development approach.

How To.title: East Belfast Enterprise
How To.summary: An incubation workspace hosting training/mentoring initiatives to support new and established businesses in the local area. The company works for the benefit of businesses in areas of Belfast and surrounding areas through a partnership approach with other organisations.

How To.title: Community Advice Services
How To.summary: This resource links you to a service providing a free, independent, accessible and confidential advice, information and representation service using a community development approach.

How To.title: Community Resource and Finance
How To.summary: This resource links you to a service promoting good financial management practice in the community sector by offering financial management advice, training services and a community accountancy service.

How To.title: Colin Glen - Social Economy
How To.summary: This resource links you to a social economy trust that is dedicated to enhancing local communities by providing a range of modern facilities for developing individuals and improving their quality of life.

How To.title: Footprints Community Garden
How To.summary: This resource links you to a community garden that is an open place to grow organic food as well as opportunities for recreation, volunteering, exercise, therapy and education.

How To.title: Building Your Future Project
How To.summary: This resource links you to a community centre providing employment programmes in all sectors for adults not in work and/or economically inactive.

Case Study.title: Ashton FabLab
Case Study.summary: An innovative makerspace that includes a 3D printer, a laser cutter, CNC router, full electronics station, and a large scale vinyl cutter.
Case Study.body: A FabLab (Digital Fabrication Laboratory) is halfway between a laboratory and a workshop. It’s a place where you can make (almost) anything, where both small children and inventors can turn an idea into reality.

Case Study.title: Peace Walls Project
Case Study.summary: A group that assists communities impacted by the peace walls and physical barriers, providing a range of confidence and relationship building interventions within and between interface communities.
Case Study.body: A partnership between Cliftonville Community Regeneration Forum (CCRF) and Lower Oldpark Community Association (LOCA). Our Peace Walls Programme focuses on three key areas of work: (1) Robust Community Consultations (2) Relationship building (3) Creating attitudinal change.

Case Study.title: Art Learning Projects
Case Study.summary: A neutral venue for the presentation of contemporary visual art and associated creative and educational activities located on an interface in North Belfast.
Case Study.body: A neutral venue for creative and educational activities located on an interface in North Belfast providing an environment where the residents of Belfast regardless of political religious ethnic or sensual persuasion can experience contemporary visual art.

Case Study.title: North Belfast Men's Shed
Case Study.summary: An enterprise where men make and sell their own products, communicate and socialise, and support each other when in need.
Case Study.body: A place where men can talk to each other about different things that are going on in their lives. If they have any kind of issues they support each other through it.

Case Study.title: Kitchen Crisis
Case Study.summary: A sustainable community food growing, donation, and collection project.
Case Study.body: A sustainable community food project. Includes opportunities to Grow food in our community garden, Donate food from your fridge or cupboard, Collect food from local stores, Cook up a storm in the kitchen, Help us organise all the food as it comes in Deliver it to those in need.

Case Study.title: Belfast South - Digital Hub
Case Study.summary: A range of equipment such as 3D printing, laser cutting, coding, photography, STEAM activities, sublimation with training, education and programmes.
Case Study.body: A digital hub that boasts a range of equipment that can help unleash your potential through: 3D printing, laser cutting, coding, photography, STEAM activities, sublimation and lots more.

Case Study.title: The Crescent Hub
Case Study.summary: A space that has been home to many arts organisations - DoubleBand Films, Fortnight Magazine, Belfast Community Circus, Open Arts, The Fenderesky Gallery and others.
Case Study.body: The Crescent has been home to many arts organisations - DoubleBand Films, Fortnight Magazine, Belfast Community Circus, Open Arts, The Fenderesky Gallery - to name but a few. We continue to be a home for creative organisations, many of them deeply connected into activity in the building. We are proud to be an Arts Centre that is both a home to, and platform, for so much talent and knowledge, and connected into multiple networks across Belfast, Northern Ireland, and beyond.

Case Study.title: Engaging for Change
Case Study.summary: A 26 week programme aimed at getting 8 ‘NEET’ young people (ages 14-20) back into education, training and employment.
Case Study.body: A 26 week programme aimed at getting 8 ‘NEET’ young people (ages 14 -20) back into education, training and employment tailored to the individual needs of the young people.

Case Study.title: Creating Cohesive Community
Case Study.summary: A service providing a three days’ nutritionally balanced emergency food and support to local people who are referred to us in crisis.
Case Study.body: Project developed out of a Belfast City Council’s PEACE III Strategic Grants Programme to improve relations across communities.

Case Study.title: Refresh Café
Case Study.summary: This resource links you to a social enterprise helping a thousand vulnerable people every week to have a roof over their heads, get into work and improve their mental health
Case Study.body: Is a social enterprise, our proﬁts enable East Belfast Mission to help a thousand vulnerable people every week to have a roof over their heads, get into work and improve their mental health. Every weekday we provide hot meals to over 250 local people who otherwise wouldn’t get a good nutritious meal and we provide training for scores of people who are unemployed, helping them get back into work. We deliver even more than great tasting food – we make food that does good. We pride ourselves on excellent customer service and a warm welcome for everyone. The cafe sources the finest local ingredients to create great tasting food.

Case Study.title: Restore Shops
Case Study.summary: This resource links you to a social economy project selling a range of good quality second hand clothes, furniture, books, bric-a-brac, refurbished furniture, bikes and other household items.
Case Study.body: Restore is a social economy project of East Belfast Mission. Social Economy is also known as “not-for-profit” as income is used to sustain and further develop social and environmental aims within an organisation rather than being distributed to financial investors. Restore sells a range of good quality second hand clothes, furniture, books, bric-a-brac, refurbished furniture and bikes and other household items such as mirrors and pictures.

Case Study.title: Hosforad
Case Study.summary: This resource links you to a service supporting people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness through a homeless hostel and a tenancy support service.
Case Study.body: Hosford is the homeless service of East Belfast Mission based in the Skainos Centre on the Lower Newtownards Road in East Belfast and for over 20 years Hosford has provided services to people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness. Hosford provides two main services a homeless hostel containing 26 rooms/apartments for people who have lost their home and a Tenancy Support Service. The tenancy support service is available for people who have their own home to help them maintain their independence and avoid homelessness.

Case Study.title: The Foundry
Case Study.summary: This resource links you to a space fostering collaboration in a shared and supportive space, offering bench desking for up to 21 people and 10 small offices designed with a young and fresh startup in mind.
Case Study.body: The Foundry is much more than just a desk and internet access, it’s an energising environment that fosters collaboration in a shared and supportive space. The Foundry is a co-working space offering bench desking for up to 21 people and 10 small offices designed with a young and fresh startup in mind who value privacy yet still want to be part of a collaborative vibe. We have a meeting room that can accommodate 6 people and a breakout area, communal kitchen, flat-screen TV, complimentary tea & coffee and current business magazines. We have also designed a studio/creative space for clients who need specific design space and unique desk layout to facilitate drawing and computer work. The mixture of open plan desks, small 2/3 man offices and studio/creative space offers our clients an alternative to just a boring desk in either a cramped uninspiring office or working from home.

Case Study.title: Community Counselling
Case Study.summary: This resource links you to a service providing accessible, confidential counselling in East Belfast
Case Study.body: Our aim is to provide accessible, confidential counselling in East Belfast. This includes services such as life coaching as well.

Case Study.title: Feel Good with Food
Case Study.summary: This resource links you to a cooking group that is free of charge to those living and working in the Urban Village area of East Belfast.

Case Study.title: Eastside Voices Tour
Case Study.summary: This resource links you to a tour involving authentic stories of conflict, division and pain that came to these streets from local guides who have been personally affected but yet remained resilient against adversity.
Case Study.body: Hear authentic stories of conflict, division and pain that came to these streets from local guides who have been personally affected but yet remained resilient against adversity; as they guide you on a journey of discovery, understanding, and awareness of how communities who were once at war are now working together to promote community-led tourism and peacebuilding.

Case Study.title: Community Counselling
Case Study.summary: This resource links you to a community based counselling service for adults, young people, and those with special needs.
Case Study.body: Community based counselling for adults, young people, and those with special needs such as the deaf.

Case Study.title: Colin Connect
Case Study.summary: This resource links you to the Colin Connect Transport Hub that includes two community managed spaces and a civic square that can be used to host a variety of public events and community activities.
Case Study.body: The new transport hub and civic square forms part of a major investment in the Colin area which is being supported through the Urban Villages Initiative. The Colin Connect Transport Hub has already improved the physical environment and offers new connections linking West Belfast, East Belfast and Titanic Quarter via the city centre on the Translink Glider service. The hub also includes two community spaces which will be managed by Colin Neighbourhood Partnership, who will also use the civic square to host a variety of public events and community activities.

Case Study.title: Colin Summer Festival
Case Study.summary: This resource links you to a free festival organised by the Colin Neighbourhood Partnership that includes a Family fun day.
Case Study.body: The festival, organised by Colin Neighbourhood Partnership and funded by the Urban Villages Initiative, will feature a range of events for all the family to get involved in. Highlights include the annual Colin Summer Festival Parade and Family Fun Day on Thursday 8th August. This annual carnival parade will make its way up from St Luke’s Church in Twinbrook, along the Stewartstown Road, to the new Colin Town square for a free Family Fun Day. Here there will be carnival rides, face painters, live music, arts and crafts, talent competitions, bouncy castles and much more. This free event is guaranteed to keep the kids entertained for hours!

Projects.name: Shared Green Space for Bogside Residence
Projects.description: We plan on starting a community garden for Bogside residents, with open access to locals and passers by. We plan to run informative classes, make room for composting local food waste and allow a space for community veg and flower beds. We need a space for a shed and are looking at putting in a proposal with the council for using land between Fern Rd and Glencow Park.

general.content: this is the general chat for the plan stage

funding.content: this is the funding chat for the plan stage

location.content: this is the location chat for the plan stage

dates.content: this is the dates chat for the plan stage

general.content: this is the general chat for the act stage

funding.content: this is the funding chat for the act stage

location.content: this is the location chat for the act stage

dates.content: this is the dates chat for the act stage

chat.content: so, how do we think that went?

Projects.name: Health & Hygiene Training – Available to Bogside residents
Projects.description: There is free Health & Hygiene Cert training available for most residents in the Bogside area. If you are interested please contact me via the platform or message directly, there will be a short questionnaire you will need to fill which I can also share here. From our account I hope to keep everyone informed of timings and logistics once we reach minimum numbers of 13 attendees. Please drop me a line if interested or better yet complete the questionnaire and send back to me!

Projects.name: Árainn Mhór Arts Club
Projects.description:
I’ve been an art teacher for most of my professional career and look to start an informal but hopefully lively Art’s Club for the Island, mainly to have fun and to keep me out of trouble! 
All ages and abilities are welcome! 
The syllabus is as a follows: 
1. Fundamental techniques - Watercolours
2. Basic clay sculptures – Glazing and Firing your finished piece  
3. Anime crash course  - One stop shop to get your anime inked and digitised
5. Photoshop painting – I’m offering a basic course in how to draw digitally using Adobe software, limited spaces due to tablets!
6. Basic Video editing – Using the computers in the Hub on every other Sunday we’ll be running basic editing skills for any video content you want to showcase.
Let’s get our hands dirty!

Projects.name: Tidy Up! Campaign
Projects.description:
You know the score! Let’s get the rubbish off the floor!! 
We’re setting up a working group to deal with and manage the increasing amounts of rubbish coming onto the island from the summer’s influx of tourists. 
It’s kicking off from scratch so we want to get around a governance model that can work for everyone and keep us on track.  Volunteers are most welcome. 
We first hope to deal with some of the issues first hand but also look to get support and hopefully make enough noise to get some leverage on the issue from the government. 
Bring your energy and opinions and let’s get cracking. Go raibh maith agat!

Projects.name: Fundraising Marathon for Ardoyne Youth Enterprise
Projects.description:
I plan to organize a marathon with the aid of members of the Ardoyne Youth Club to help raise funds for centre. I’ve got my costume ready!: the Marvel Character Deadpool and hope to set up the project from here…
-logistics
- budgets
- promotion 
- participants
- licensing
Particularly would love some help with licenses – any one done this before?! and promotion is something I’ve never ever ever done before! We have a target of roughly 30 runners and would like to accommodate as many participants as we can muster…

Projects.name: New food coop & Seed bank
Projects.description: During the pandemic myself, friends and relatives felt the shock of items missing from the supermarket, coupled with the post pandemic rising cost of living we began actively trying to secure some of our necessities in bulk. Pooling together helped keep costs down! So here we plan to establish a formalised food coop that allows us to up our spending power and get food in together to keep prices down.  Part of our learning also lead us to find out about seed banks and maintaining personal stocks for gardeners and households. We’ve yet to dabble in it but would also like to offer a forum for folks to share any good local seed they have been successful in growing and harvesting.

Projects.name: Non Violent Communication Working Group
Projects.description: Nonviolent Communication is an approach to communication based on principles of nonviolence. It is not a technique to end disagreements, but rather a method designed to increase empathy and improve the quality of life of those who utilize the method and the people around them. Everyone could gain from learning how to better communicate and we hope to help our community better understand each other in daily practice. We have trainers a small budget from the council and look to organise a venue and quarterly schedule of courses. Using the platform we hope to garner interest and get the ground work established for the project to be successfully run in the autumn of 2022.

Projects.name: Colin's New Man Shed
Projects.description: Taking the lead from some of the successful man sheds in the city we plan to set up are own for older gentlemen in the Colin community. We have Strong ties with the Colin Neighbourhood Partnership (CNP) who are happy to help, we hope to get the ball rolling once a group is assembled and plan is drawn to seek or raise funding.

Projects.name: Save the Moat park Fairies Campaign
Projects.description:
Moat Park’s Fairie community is under-threat. We need you to help us! 
- Tidy up and renovate the current Fairie Village start of the Easter Holidays
- Run 2-3 weekend sessions for youngsters to get more Fairie homes made.

We’re setting a small group to self organise here during the winter and get the events underway next spring.

Projects.name: Lessons – ‘I am learning Irish (Tá mé ag foghlaim na Gaeilge)
Projects.description: Were taking it back lads, old school. Let’s learn Irish together, myself and a group of Irish speaker’s started a successful facegroup that’s been running since 2016, we hope to formalise some our practice into classes and events in the community.

Projects.name: Donegall Pass Community Centre - 2x Positions
Projects.description:
We’re looking for two new part time youth team leaders to self start and run some training for the next 6-8 months. 
The brief is your own to create but you must provide a compelling work schedule from the syllabus we will share here, suitable candidates will also need appropriate up-to-date qualifications and a formatted CV.
We’ll be managing applications for this proposal on this platform in order to help field questions around the application process mentioned. 
Please join the group if interested and sharpen your pencils for the applications opening; we will be posting all information here in the coming weeks and applications will be open April 10th 12:00 noon and will close April 30th.

Projects.name: New Seeds – Help co-design and plant new flower beds at the end of Eureka Drive
Projects.description: With the help of the community centre I’ve negotiated some space to plant some flowers on some land that the council has no use for currently. No big plans just some Saturday mornings to make an excuse for coffee and cake. I am happy to host as I’m local and an easy walk to the plot. We can take a look and then workshop at mine. So we are all happy before sowing in the spring. My friend’s daugher Catriona Jones is the local community gardener for area will be joining the group and will give tips and advice and approve our final design. Please feel free to bring your favorite biscuits or cake and I’ll have the kettle ready and everything else we’ll need. I’m posting a call out on my street’s whatsapp group and the local parent’s facebook also. I’ll keep you all informed of timings and post up our designs as they go here.
